div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 310px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 100px; overflow: hidden;

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 190px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 200px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 940px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 120px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Actions provide a mechanism to package up all the information required to perform a specific modification to a system. This is fundamentally required as we may occasionally desire to stage modifications behind a human approval gate

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 910px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 430px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 190px; overflow: hidden;

border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 200px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Actions provide a mechanism to package up all the information required to perform a specific modification to a system. This is fundamentally required as we may occasionally desire to stage modifications behind a human approval gate

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;

div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;

border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

h2.div: Actions provide a mechanism to package up all the information required to perform a specific modification to a system. This is fundamentally required as we may occasionally desire to stage modifications behind a human approval gate

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;

div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;

border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;

div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 765px;

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 765px;

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.p: In this version of this program we migrate to an architecture that treats a block device as a series of interconnected layers. This view was inspired by the fact that certain operations could only be performed on a block device unless the device was formatted or mounted. This program will iterate through each device, layer by layer, until it brings a block device to its desired state

div.div: Responsible for ensuring that the Config only contains data that is sensible with regards to the system. For example, OwnerValidator will ensure that any users or groups, mentioned in the Config, actually exist on the system.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 310px; margin-left: 5px;

div.div: Responsible for storing the desired state of devices on the system and the execution mode for a specific device

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 5px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 360px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: While it would be ideal that the Config is immutable, there are certain conditions that require us to perform modifications to the configuration declared on file.

The limitation of the NVMe Driver on Nitro-enabled EC2 Instances is that they rename attached block devices on a FIFO basis. This would mean that a EBS volume attached through the API as /dev/sdb could get potentially renamed to /dev/nvme0n[0-9]+.
Fortunately, AWS provides us a mechanism to recover the original block device mapping by querying the NVMe IOCTL interface [Reference]
The aim of this modifier is to replace any references to recovered block device mapping (/dev/sdb) with the actual block device name (/dev/nvme0n[0-9]+)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 570px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.div: In this phase, we enrich the layer with information from the various backends it might orchestrate. Some layers might require information from multiple backends to achieve the desired goal of getting a block device to a specific state.
The purpose of this phase is to generate an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system so that we can efficiently query it later.

In this phase, we query the enriched layer and decide what actions need to be generated in order to get the block device to a desired state. The user must then approve the suggested changes or delegate the program to decide whether they are executed or refused.

During this phase, we can perform some pre-flight checks to determine whether modifying the system is actually feasible. For example, you cannot format a device that already has a file system or we cannot mount a device to directory that doesn't exist

After modifications are performed (if any), then we enrich the layer once again and then confirm whether the devices are in the desired state. This is necessary as the layers are dependent on the successful validation of the one above it (e.g Devices cannot be labelled, until they have a valid file system)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 560px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 190px; overflow: hidden;

border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends provide an in-memory representation of a sub-section of our system. For example the FileBackend provides a data view of specific files in our file system and the DeviceBackend provides a data view of specific block devices attached to our system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Backends only possess the ability to query the system and suggest Actions. It is outside its responsibility to execute these actions.

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 760px; margin-left: 765px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 200px; overflow: hidden;

border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: All queries and modifications to the system are performed at the Service level. Certain services cannot get the information they require through standard libraries, so they delegate that work to C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
div.span: These C-based utilities are invoked through Runners that correspond to a specific Binary

h2.div: Binaries are enums that ensure that we only invoke approved commands. They are a great tool to visualise the external dependencies of this program

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;

h2.div: Runners provide a shell mechanism for this program to invoke C-based utilities that are pre-installed on most Linux distros. Runners also contain logic to validate whether they are actually installed on the system.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;

h2.div: Possesses logic to ensure that Runners are instantiated on an as-needs basis and then cached for future use. This is to ensure that we are not constantly validating the accessibility of the underlying Binary

h2.div: Actions provide a mechanism to package up all the information required to perform a specific modification to a system. This is fundamentally required as we may occasionally desire to stage modifications behind a human approval gate

div.div: A mode that ensures that an action is never executed and causes the program to exit early. This mode ensures the program can run in a hardened state where block devices are validated against a Config and any detected actions imply that system is not in the desired state.

div.style: font-weight: 400; border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: This mode will be the only mode that we recommend for common usage. It is a way of protecting us from liability

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode that ensures that an Action must require human approval before it is executed. It is a great way of permitting changes to a system in a controlled manner.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
border-color: var(--border-color);
border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px;
border-color: var(--border-color);

div.div: A mode where we put ultimate trust in the programs ability to decide whether an action is sensible to execute. Despite the naming, the program will operate conservatively, avoiding certain destructive operations like formatting existing file systems.

div.style: border-color: var(--border-color); font-size: 12px; font-weight: 400;
